stem: The nurse is planning the timing of insulin administration and meal coordination. Match each insulin type with its correct onset, peak, and duration profile.

columns.text: Onset: 15 min; Peak: 1-2 hr; Duration: 3-5 hr
Onset: 30-60 min; Peak: 2-4 hr; Duration: 5-8 hr
Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: 4-12 hr; Duration: 18-24 hr
Onset: 1-2 hr; Peak: None (Plateau); Duration: 24+ hr

rationale.correct: Timing is everything in insulin safety. (r1) Rapid-acting insulin ('Log' insulins) must be given 'when the tray is in the room'. (r2) Regular insulin is the only one typically given IV and has a 30-min lead time. (r3) NPH is cloudy and peaks in the afternoon/evening if given in the morning. (r4) Long-acting insulins ('L' insulins) provide a steady baseline with no peak, reducing hypoglycemia risk.
rationale.incorrect: Long-acting insulin (Glargine) should not be mixed in the same syringe with any other insulin.
clinicalPearls: Regular insulin is the only insulin that can be administered intravenously in cases of DKA.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that Glargine/Lantus has NO peak. If an answer choice says it peaks at 12 hours, it's incorrect!

mnemonic.title: R-S-I-L
mnemonic.expansion: Rapid, Short, Intermediate, Long. (15 min, 30 min, 1 hr, 1 hr).

reviewUnits.heading: Insulin Administration Standards
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must recognize the peak times to monitor for hypoglycemia. Mixing insulin follows the 'Clear before Cloudy' rule (Regular before NPH).
